history.content:
Yes, you need to be an actual junior/senior to have access to the reserved seats. Its specific for this class.

Why this is the case is a question for the department to answer. Though I feel this is done so as to allow juniors and seniors to take this class for the upcoming Data Science major so that they can still have enough time to fulfill the new major's requirements before they graduate.

children.subject:
I am in the same position as you and was wondering that as well - not sure why it is the case.

If anyone knows, I am 113 on the Data 100 waitlist. Should I drop it and get into something that is open right now? I had a pretty late phase 1 and my phase 2 appears to be late as well, so I am not sure if I will get into other technicals by then if I don't get into this one. Is it likely that I get in with that position on the waitlist?

history.content: It seems arbitrary and unfair to say that when enrollment for c100 is handled by CS, we won't let other juniors and seniors in but when it is handled by STAT they (possibly) wouldn't let CS juniors and seniors in at all.  We follow the lead of the DS initiative in determining enrollment priorities for DS classes.

children.subject: How can I view the page you screenshotted? I cannot find it.

history.content: I was waitlisted for CS C100, even though on the academic guide it says that there are still open seats for juniors and seniors. I'm an undeclared sophomore with junior standing, so if I was waitlisted for the class, does that mean I need to be an actual junior/senior or be declared CS to enroll directly? I thought this was odd because other CS upper divs specify that they have reserved seats for declared CS and EECS majors, but CS C100 only specifies that it has reserved seats for juniors/seniors. Can anyone explain why I was placed on the waitlist?
history.subject: Waitlisted for CS C100
